metadata.feature_description: Show activity indicator icon for users with viewable activities

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Display activity icon for regular users

steps.action: Navigated to Admin > Users panel and viewed user list
steps.expected: Activity icon should be visible for regular (non-SuperUser) users
steps.actual: Activity icon (User Activity) is displayed for all regular users including Regular TestUser, Claude TestUser, Test User123, etc. Each user row shows the activity icon along with Profile Settings, Account Settings, and User Roles icons.

steps.action: Searched for 'host' to find the SuperUser account
steps.expected: Activity icon should NOT be visible for SuperUser accounts
steps.actual: The SuperUser Account (host) row displays only Profile Settings and Account Settings icons. The User Activity icon and User Roles icon are NOT displayed, confirming the code logic that hides activity icons for SuperUsers (isSuperUser check in showUserActivity function).

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Verify icon click opens activity tab

steps.action: Clicked the User Activity icon for Regular TestUser
steps.expected: Activity details panel should open showing user's activity information
steps.actual: The User Activity panel expanded showing comprehensive activity details: Last Active (7 minutes ago), Recent Activity (Joined Site 3 hours ago - Evoq Content Library), Rank (4), Reputation (10), Experience (20), Edit Points button, Engagement (0), Influence (0), and Total Contributions (0).

observations: Code analysis confirms the showUserActivity function in permissionHelpers.js returns false for SuperUsers: return !user.isSuperUser && (settings.isAdmin || settings.permissions.SHOW_USER_ACTIVITY)
The activity icon uses SvgIcons.ActivityIcon with title 'ShowUserActivity.title' as defined in getUserTabsIcons function
The UserActivityDetails component displays comprehensive user engagement metrics including Rank, Reputation, Experience, Engagement, Influence, and Total Contributions
SHOW_USER_ACTIVITY permission requirement was not explicitly tested as the logged-in SuperUser (host) has admin rights which grants access automatically
